title: The Vaccine Mandate Kicks In at 100 Employees. What If You’re at 98?
content: For small businesses hovering just under the federal vaccination guidelines, navigating this period is tricky.

title: When a Logo Doesn’t Risk It All: Meta’s Brand Is Designed for Unknown Worlds
content: The emblem for Facebook’s new parent company is built for the metaverse, even if it disappoints in the real world.

title: A Chastened Alibaba Tones Down Its Singles Day Retail Bonanza
content: The Chinese e-commerce giant is updating its blockbuster shopping holiday for a humbler, more dutiful era in the country’s internet industry.

title: G.E. Breaks Up With Its Storied Past
content: The company, once the epitome of corporate ambition, plans to split itself into three separate companies.

more_info.byline: By Steve Lohr and Michael J. de la Merced

title: Moderna and U.S. at Odds Over Vaccine Patent Rights
content: Moderna’s patent application names several employees as the sole inventors of a crucial component of its coronavirus vaccine, excluding three government scientists.

more_info.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins

title: The Biggest Kink in America’s Supply Chain: Not Enough Truckers
content: Long hours and uncomfortable working conditions are leading to a shortage of truck drivers, which has compounded shipping delays in the United States.

more_info.byline: By Madeleine Ngo and Ana Swanson

title: How Data Is Reshaping Real Estate
content: Tech start-ups are offering new tools to help retailers and entertainment venues be more efficient by counting crowds, tracking foot traffic and following local shopping habits.

title: Brian Williams Says He’s Leaving NBC News
content: The former anchor of “NBC Nightly News” rehabilitated his tarnished image as the host of a popular 11 p.m. show on MSNBC.

title: China, Electric Vehicles and More at the DealBook Online Summit
content: What we want to know from Secretary of State Antony Blinken, G.M.’s Mary Barra, the podcast hosts Dax Shepard and Monica Padman, and more.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: Google loses appeal of $2.8 billion fine in E.U. antitrust case.
content: European antitrust regulators said Google gave preferential treatment to its own price-comparison shopping service over rival services.

title: Inflation spiked in October, sinking Washington’s hopes that price gains would slow down.
content: The Consumer Price Index rose 6.2 percent in October from a year ago, its fastest increase since 1990. That is bad news for President Biden and the central bank.

title: Rivian will start trading today after an I.P.O. valuing it at nearly $70 billion.
content: The company, backed by Amazon and Ford, has delivered only 156 trucks so far, but its market worth approaches that of Ford.

more_info.byline: By Peter Eavis and Neal E. Boudette

title: Judge denies Apple’s request to delay App Store changes.
content: Apple may have to rewrite its policies to allow app developers to point users to alternative payment methods as soon as December.

title: Pfizer Asks F.D.A. to Expand Booster Eligibility to All Adults
content: In a turnaround, the agency is expected to grant the request before the winter holiday season, giving access to all 181 million fully vaccinated people.

title: Matthew McConaughey on Covid, masks and vaccines for children.
content: The actor and author Matthew McConaughey is contemplating a run for governor of Texas.

title: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, says paid family leave ‘is not just about the mom.’
content: “It sets us up for economic growth and success, but it also just allows people to have that very sacred time as a family.”

title: Oklahoma Supreme Court Throws Out $465 Million Opioid Ruling Against J.&J.
content: The 5-1 decision is a setback for those who are fighting to hold big drug makers accountable for the opioid epidemic.

title: Workhorse Group records a big loss on electric vans.
content: The company, which lost its bid for a big Postal Service contract, has told investors it is under federal investigation.

title: Meta plans to remove thousands of sensitive ad-targeting categories.
content: Ad buyers will no longer be able to use topics such as health, race or sexual orientation to target people with unwanted ads on Facebook or other Meta apps.

more_info.byline: By Mike Isaac and Tiffany Hsu

title: Starbucks workers at three more Buffalo-area stores file for union elections.
content: The petitions were submitted as employees at three other stores prepared to vote in a unionization effort.

title: New Initiative Aims to Change How Movies Portray Muslims
content: An advocacy group has created a worker database with help from Disney to bring more Muslims into the filmmaking process.

title: ‘It went to my head’: Adam Neumann has regrets about his time at WeWork.
content: He also tried to revise the record about what happened.

more_info.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

title: Tesla shares slide 12 percent as Musk’s stock-sale pledge continues to reverberate.
content: Since Friday, Tesla has shed about $200 billion in market valuation.

title: Twitter expands its subscription service to news articles.
content: The company is pushing to find new sources of revenue.

title: Tim Cook has invested in cryptocurrency personally, but Apple has no plans to do so.
content: “I think it’s reasonable to own it as part of a diversified portfolio,” Apple’s chief executive said at the DealBook Online Summit.

more_info.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

title: Hearst’s magazine journalists protest a mandatory return to the office.
content: The company’s journalists joined the Writers Guild in 2020 and have asked in contract talks for a flexible work arrangement. The company has rejected that request.

title: As China’s Property Crisis Spreads, Beijing Says There’s Nothing to See
content: Global markets just weeks ago were fretting over the possible failure of Evergrande. Now the developer says the worst is over, even as other companies show signs of trouble.

more_info.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong

title: What’s happening today at the DealBook summit.
Rolls-Royce plans to build small nuclear power plants in Britain.
content: Backed by the government and other investors, the industrial giant proposes to build as many as 16 generating plants.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
content: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

title: Top Questions for the DealBook Online Summit
content: What we would like to ask Apple’s Tim Cook, the WeWork founder Adam Neumann, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, and more.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: The Fed warns that China’s property market stress poses a risk to the U.S.
content: The U.S. central bank voiced concern as China Evergrande’s debt troubles have raised alarm in global financial markets and at home.

title: Powell’s Books Survived Amazon. Can It Reinvent Itself After the Pandemic?
content: As much as any city, Portland, Ore., has been through hell. Its landmark store, Powell’s Books, must finally build a viable online business while recapturing its downtown success.
